node.contents: If you have an ExecutorService which is a thread pool and a queue, why do you have another thread and another queue to add tasks to it? I would have the executor pool do everything which simplifies shutting it down. Without the extra thread and queue, the code would be much simpler.

astNode.text: If you have an ExecutorService which is a thread pool and a queue, why do you have another thread and another queue to add tasks to it? I would have the executor pool do everything which simplifies shutting it down. Without the extra thread and queue, the code would be much simpler.

node.contents: 'nextSteps = step.execute();' : is this class (not shown) free of any suspicion?

astNode.text: 'nextSteps = step.execute();' : is this class (not shown) free of any suspicion?

node.contents: I'm using a ConcurrentLinkedQueue to store computational steps, and an ExecutorService created by Executors.newFixedThreadPool to execute them out. My problem is that the application never terminates. Here's some code:

astNode.text: I'm using a ConcurrentLinkedQueue to store computational steps, and an ExecutorService created by Executors.newFixedThreadPool to execute them out. My problem is that the application never terminates. Here's some code:

elements.contents: public class Run { public static void main (String[] args) throws Exception { ParallelExecutor executor = new ParallelExecutor(); executor.execute(); // manual shutdown Thread.sleep(30 * 1000); executor.stop(); // the main thread dies, the application keeps running }

comments.text: // manual shutdown Thread.sleep(30 * 1000); executor.stop(); // the main thread dies, the application keeps running }
// manual shutdown Thread.sleep(30 * 1000); executor.stop(); // the main thread dies, the application keeps running }

elements.contents: public class ParallelExecutor implements Runnable { // stores executions steps to private ConcurrentLinkedQueue<ExecutionStep> queue = new ConcurrentLinkedQueue<ExecutionStep>(); private ExecutorService threadPoolExecutor = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(10); private Thread feedingThread = new Thread(this); public void execute() { ExecutionStep step = new ConcreteExecutionStep(); this.queue.add(step); this.feedingThread.start(); } public void stop() { if (log.isInfoEnabled()) { log.info("Shutting down"); } this.queue = new ConcurrentLinkedQueue<ExecutionStep>(); try { this.feedingThread.join(0); this.threadPoolExecutor.shutdownNow(); } catch (InterruptedException e) { log.warn("Something happened!", e); } } public void run() { while (true) { if (this.threadPoolExecutor.isShutdown()) { return; } try { Thread.sleep(this.waitMillis); } catch (InterruptedException e) { // NOP } if (!this.queue.isEmpty()) { this.threadPoolExecutor.execute(new Runnable() { @Override public void run() { ExecutionStep step = this.queue.poll(); List<ExecutionStep> nextSteps = Collections.emptyList(); try { nextSteps = step.execute(); } catch (Exception e) { // NOP } // here we feed the queue this.queue.addAll(nextSteps); } }); } } }

comments.text: // stores executions steps to private ConcurrentLinkedQueue<ExecutionStep> queue = new ConcurrentLinkedQueue<ExecutionStep>(); private ExecutorService threadPoolExecutor = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(10); private Thread feedingThread = new Thread(this); public void execute() { ExecutionStep step = new ConcreteExecutionStep(); this.queue.add(step); this.feedingThread.start(); } public void stop() { if (log.isInfoEnabled()) { log.info("Shutting down"); } this.queue = new ConcurrentLinkedQueue<ExecutionStep>(); try { this.feedingThread.join(0); this.threadPoolExecutor.shutdownNow(); } catch (InterruptedException e) { log.warn("Something happened!", e); } } public void run() { while (true) { if (this.threadPoolExecutor.isShutdown()) { return; } try { Thread.sleep(this.waitMillis); } catch (InterruptedException e) { // NOP } if (!this.queue.isEmpty()) { this.threadPoolExecutor.execute(new Runnable() { @Override public void run() { ExecutionStep step = this.queue.poll(); List<ExecutionStep> nextSteps = Collections.emptyList(); try { nextSteps = step.execute(); } catch (Exception e) { // NOP } // here we feed the queue this.queue.addAll(nextSteps); } }); } } }

node.contents: EDIT: The problem was due to another executor being (silently) started in the code I cut out before posting the question, as I thought it irrelevant. Anyway, Peter Lawrey answer is still valuable input, hence it got accepted.

astNode.text: EDIT: The problem was due to another executor being (silently) started in the code I cut out before posting the question, as I thought it irrelevant. Anyway, Peter Lawrey answer is still valuable input, hence it got accepted.

node.contents: but this behavior is in contradiction with his comment at the end of the main: "main thread dies". So he was incorrect saying that?

astNode.text: but this behavior is in contradiction with his comment at the end of the main: "main thread dies". So he was incorrect saying that?

node.contents: I confirm the main thread dies. I edited my original question to show the thread dump during the endless waiting state at the end of every execution.

astNode.text: I confirm the main thread dies. I edited my original question to show the thread dump during the endless waiting state at the end of every execution.

node.contents: Yes, the main thread will block in 'executor.stop();'.

astNode.text: Yes, the main thread will block in 'executor.stop();'.

node.contents: I also tried to join the `feedingThread` *after* shutting down the thread executor. Same behavior.

astNode.text: I also tried to join the `feedingThread` *after* shutting down the thread executor. Same behavior.

node.contents: You are waiting for feedingThread to terminate (feedingThread.join(0)) before you shut down the executor and the feeding thread will continue in its while(true)-loop until the executor is stopped.

astNode.text: You are waiting for feedingThread to terminate (feedingThread.join(0)) before you shut down the executor and the feeding thread will continue in its while(true)-loop until the executor is stopped.

node.contents: It definitely makes sense to just strip out the unnecessary queue. I'll refactor my code, test your proposal and let you know. Thanks.

astNode.text: It definitely makes sense to just strip out the unnecessary queue. I'll refactor my code, test your proposal and let you know. Thanks.

node.contents: Thanks for your input, the problem turned out to be caused by something invisible here, as I removed the relevant code thinking it was.. irrelevant :-) In any case, your answer is still quite useful for everyone searching SO for Executors hints.

astNode.text: Thanks for your input, the problem turned out to be caused by something invisible here, as I removed the relevant code thinking it was.. irrelevant :-) In any case, your answer is still quite useful for everyone searching SO for Executors hints.

node.contents: This will shut down provided there is no work being done and it won't pause from time to time which is slowing down your application and could be making it appear nothing is happening.

astNode.text: This will shut down provided there is no work being done and it won't pause from time to time which is slowing down your application and could be making it appear nothing is happening.

elements.contents: public class ParallelExecutor { interface ExecutionStep { List<ExecutionStep> execute(); } public static final int N_THREADS = Runtime.getRuntime().availableProcessors(); private final ExecutorService executorService = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(N_THREADS); public void execute(final ExecutionStep step) { executorService.submit(new Runnable() { @Override public void run() { for (ExecutionStep es : step.execute()) execute(es); } }); } public void stop() { this.executorService.shutdownNow(); } }

units.rawText: public class ParallelExecutor { interface ExecutionStep { List<ExecutionStep> execute(); } public static final int N_THREADS = Runtime.getRuntime().availableProcessors(); private final ExecutorService executorService = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(N_THREADS); public void execute(final ExecutionStep step) { executorService.submit(new Runnable() { @Override public void run() { for (ExecutionStep es : step.execute()) execute(es); } }); } public void stop() { this.executorService.shutdownNow(); } }

elements.contents: ParallelExecutor executor = new ParallelExecutor(); executor.execute(new ConcreteExecutionStep()); // manual shutdown Thread.sleep(30 * 1000); executor.stop();

units.rawText: ParallelExecutor executor = new ParallelExecutor(); executorexecute(new ConcreteExecutionStep()); // manual shutdown Thread.sleep(30 * 1000); executor.stop();

node.contents: You can also unplug your computer.

astNode.text: You can also unplug your computer.

node.contents: I found a very simple answer to that. If you don't just return from your main function, but end it with System.exit(0), the executor will die as expected.

astNode.text: I found a very simple answer to that. If you don't just return from your main function, but end it with System.exit(0), the executor will die as expected.
